old_description: Founded in 2003, the 1920s Revolution Brigades (1920s RB) is a nationalist, Sunni organization whose main goal is to free Iraq of foreign occupation, particularly from American military and political presence. Once Iraq is free of outside influence, the 1920s RB aims to install an Iraqi government guided by Sunni Islamist principles. Today, the organization maintains a strong stance against IS. However, the Political Office of the 1920s RB opposed the participation of Arab States in the coalition against IS because the coalition conducted air strikes on the Sunni areas of Iraq in 2014.
description: Founded in 2003, the 1920s Revolution Brigades (1920s RB) was a nationalist, Sunni organization whose main goal was to free Iraq of foreign occupation, particularly from American military and political presence.
Notes: active throughout Iraq

old_description: The Abu Sayyaf Group (ASG) is an Islamic separatist organization in the Philippines founded by Abdurajak Abubakar Janjalani in 1991. Heavily influenced by Al Qaeda in its early stages, the ASG started as a splinter group of the Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) and seeks an independent Muslim state in the southern Philippines. In the early 2000s, the ASG attracted attention through high-profile bombings, assassinations, kidnappings, and attacks. It is regarded as the most dangerous group in the Philippines.
description: The Abu Sayyaf Group (ASG) is an Islamic separatist organization operating in the southern Philippines.
Notes: also operates in the Filipino capital of Manila

old_description: Ahlu Sunna Wal Jama (ASWJ) formed in 1991 to protect Sufi Muslims in Somalia. ASWJ was established in response to such groups as Al Ittihad Al Islamiya (AIAI), whose radical Islamist ideology violently opposed Sufism. The group was not a primarily militant organization prior to 2008, instead engaging in community religious affairs. ASWJ began fighting Al Shabaab in 2008 after that organization conducted several anti-Sufi attacks. ASWJ is loosely allied with Somalia¬¨√≠s Transitional Federal Government (TFG) and cooperates with it against Al Shabaab.
description: Ahlu Sunna Wal Jama (ASWJ) is a militant group formed in 1991 to protect Sufi Muslims in Somalia.

old_description: Ahrar al-Sham also known as Harakat Ahrar al-Sham al-Islamiyya, or the Islamic Movement of the Free Men of the Levant, is a Sunni Salafist militant group established in late 2011 that aims to replace the Assad Regime with an Islamic government. The group operates throughout Syria but concentrates its attacks in the north and west of the country. From its inception in 2011 until late 2013, Ahrar al-Sham cooperated with the Islamic State (IS), and launched a successful campaign to remove the Syrian army from Raqqa. However, Ahrar al-Sham and Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham, formerly known as Jabhat al-Nusra (Al-Nusra), began targeting IS after it killed an Ahrar al-Sham member in January 2014. From 2014 through 2015, Ahrar al-Sham strengthened its alliance with Al-Nusra by coordinating attacks against the Syrian army and by creating the Jaysh al-Fatah umbrella group to force the Syrian army out of Idlib province in 2015. In August 2015, Ahrar al-Sham also began negotiating ceasefire agreements with the Assad Regime on behalf of the Sunni militant groups in Idlib. However, it has not participated in further negotiations since it left a conference on a nation-wide ceasefire in December 2015.
description: Ahrar al-Sham is a Sunni Salafist militant group operating in northern Syria that was established in 2011 by amnestied Islamist prisoners in 2011. The group’s primary goal is to replace the Assad Regime with an Islamic government.

old_description: Al Akhtar Trust is a charity linked to the Taliban and Al Qaeda, and is an offshoot of the jihadi organization, Jaish-e-Muhammed . It was created in 2000 as a front of the Al Rashid Trust, another charity linked with Al Qaeda, which was designated as terrorist support group by US Department of Treasury in 2001. Al Akhtar Trust has been active in raising funds for jihad in Pakistan, Afghanistan and Iraq. One of its financiers has been linked with the kidnapping and murder of the Wall Street Journal's South Asia Bureau Chief, Daniel Pearl. Al Akhtar Trust was designated as a terrorist support group by US Department of Treasury in 2003, and as of 2010, the United Nations, the Government of Pakistan, and Interpol also list Al Akhtar Trust as a terrorist-affiliated organization.
description: Al Akhtar Trust is a charity organization that has provided aid to various militant groups in Pakistan and Afghanistan, most notably Al Qaeda.

old_description: Al Ittihad Al Islamiya (AIAI) formed in Somalia in 1984 with the goal of establishing an Islamic state in East Africa. In the late 1980s, AIAI began to focus on armed resistance against Somalia¬¨√≠s dictator, Siad Barre. AIAI mostly conducted attacks in Somalia, but after Barre¬¨√≠s overthrow in 1991, AIAI allied with the Ogaden National Liberation Front (ONLF), a separatist movement of ethnic Somalis living in Ethiopia¬¨√≠s Ogaden region, to refocus its energy on Ethiopia as its primary target. AIAI¬¨√≠s cooperation with the ONLF and attacks in Ethiopia provoked the Ethiopian government to invade Somalia in 1996 and destroy the AIAI. On January 4, 1997, AIAI announced its transition to a political party, signaling the organization¬¨√≠s effective end as a militant group. AIAI has sometimes been blamed for attacks after 1997, but these attacks were generally conducted by former AIAI members rather than a centralized organization.
description: Al Ittihad Al Islamiya was a Salafi militant organization that operated in Somalia between 1984 and 1997.
Notes: bad size estimates

description: Al Mourabitoun was a Salafi-jihadist militant organization that operated in the African Sahel region.

old_description: Al Qaeda is one of the most powerful terrorist organizations in the world, with a long history and a global reach. It is composed of a core group of operatives and leadership, largely based in Pakistan and Afghanistan, and also maintains relationships with a number of global affiliate organizations. AQ and its affiliates have been responsible for many of the deadliest terrorist attacks in the past twenty-five years.
description: Al Qaeda (AQ) is a Salafi militant organization with leadership based in Afghanistan and Pakistan and a network of members and affiliates around the world.

group_name: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
old_description: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) is a Sunni terrorist organization and Al Qaeda affiliate based in Yemen, a country whose geography and tribal social structure are often said to provide an environment friendly to terrorist and militant groups. It was created in 2009 from the merger of the Yemeni and Saudi Arabian branches of Al Qaeda. AQAP has claimed numerous attacks in the country but also targets Westerners abroad. The group is best known internationally for the ¬¨√¨underwear bomber¬¨√Æ who attempted to detonate a bomb on a Detroit-bound airplane in 2009, and for the 2015 Charlie Hebdo attacks in Paris, for which it claimed responsibility. In 2014, it created an offshoot organization called Ansar al-Sharia in Yemen in order to rebrand the AQ name in the country and attract more followers. In 2015, AQAP used the turmoil of the conflict in Yemen to seize territory in the southeast.
description: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) is a Sunni terrorist organization and Al Qaeda (AQ) affiliate based in Yemen.

group_name: Al Qaeda in the Indian Subcontinent
old_description: Al Qaeda in the Indian Subcontinent (AQIS) is an Al Qaeda-affiliated terrorist organization founded on September 3, 2014 by Al Qaeda (AQ) leader Aymenn al-Zawahiri. The group is based in Pakistan but has pledged to also carry out operations in Afghanistan, India, Bangladesh and Myanmar. In contrast to AQ leaders¬¨√≠ expectations, AQIS has been largely unsuccessful in carrying out large-scale attacks and has not attracted a significant following outside of Pakistan.
description: AQIS is an Al-Qaeda affiliated terrorist organization based in Pakistan and operating in Afghanistan, India, Bangladesh, and Myanmar.

group_name: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
old_description: AQIM, originally known as the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat (GSPC), split from the Armed Islamic Group (GIA), the main Islamist group fighting in the Algerian Civil War, in 1998. In 2006, the GSPC became a formal affiliate of Al Qaeda (AQ) and changed its name to Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM). The group is famous for kidnapping westerners for ransom in North Africa and is an active participant in the drug, arms and human trafficking trade in the region. Through these pursuits, AQIM has become one of the wealthiest terrorist organizations in the world.
description: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) is an Algerian Salafi-Jihadist militant organization operating in the African Sahel region.
other_designated_names: Canada, New Zealand, Australia, and the United Kingdom

old_description: Al Qaeda in Yemen (AQY) was the Yemeni affiliate of Al Qaeda, formed in 2000. AQY attacked the Yemeni government and Western targets in the country. In 2009, the group merged with its Saudi counterpart under the umbrella of Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP).
description: Al Qaeda in Yemen (AQY) was the Yemeni affiliate of Al Qaeda, formed in 2000.

old_description: Al Qaeda Kurdish Battalions (AQKB) is a Kurdish, Salafi militant organization affiliated with Al Qaeda (AQ) that operates in Iraqi Kurdistan. Since its formation in March 2007, the group has a primarily targeted the Kurdistan Regional Government. However, beginning in April 2014, AQKB may also be engaged fighting the Islamic State (IS).
description: Al Qaeda Kurdish Battalions (AQKB) is a Kurdish, Salafist militant organization affiliated with Al Qaeda (AQ) that operates in Iraqi Kurdistan.

old_description: Al Shabaab, meaning "The Youth" in Arabic, is the largest militant organization fighting to oust the Somalian government. The group seeks to control territory within Somalia in order to establish a society based on its rigid interpretation of Shariah law. Although based in Somalia, Al Shabaab also conducts attacks in neighboring countries, such as Kenya. Al Shabaab emerged as an independent organization around December 2006 after breaking away from the Islamic Courts Union (ICU), for which it had served as the military wing. Since the late 2000s, Al Shabaab has had close ties to Al Qaeda and has sought to frame the Somalian struggle as part of a global jihad. The group has engaged in bombings, suicide attacks, and armed assaults, especially against Somalian government targets, non-Christians, private citizens, foreign troops, diplomats, and aid or nongovernmental organization workers.
description: Al Shabaab is an affiliate organization of Al Qaeda fighting to oust the Somali government and the foreign military presence supporting it.
state_sponsor_names: Eritrea, Djibouti, Iran, Syria, Libya, Egypt, and Saudi Arabia

old_description: In July 2001, two splinter groups of the Islamic Movement in Kurdistan -- Kurdish Hamas and Tawhid -- merged to formed Al-Tawhid Islamic Front (TIF). TIF's life as an independent group was relatively short; it existed as an autonomous entity for three months in the summer of 2001 and was not credited with any major attacks. In September 2001, TIF merged with the Second Soran Unit to form Jund al-Islam.
description: On July 1, 2001, Tawhid and Hamas in Iraq (not to be confused with the unrelated Palestinian Hamas), two violent splinter groups of the Islamic Movement of Kurdistan (IMK), merged to form al-Tawhid Islamic Front (TIF).
Notes: no recorded geographic locations

old_description: The Ambazonia Defense Forces is a separatist militant organization that fights for an independent anglophone state in Cameroon.
description: The Ambazonia Defense Forces is a separatist militant organization that fights for an independent anglophone state in Cameroon.

old_description: Ansar al-Islam (AI) is a predominantly Kurdish Salafist militant organization based in Iraqi Kurdistan. The group was formed in December 2001 by a merger of several other Kurdish Islamist groups. AI had ties with Al Qaeda and fought against secular Kurdish groups as well as the U.S.-led coalition and the Iraqi government. Since 2011, the group has also fought alongside Jabhat al-Nusra and the Islamic Front in Syria. Although it had previously opposed the Islamic State (IS), AI¬¨√≠s leadership announced that the group was disbanding and merging with IS in August 2014. However, the Syrian branch of AI rejected the merger and has continued to operate in Syria as Ansar al-Islam, occasionally clashing with IS as well as the Assad government and other insurgent groups.
description: Ansar al-Islam is a Kurdish Salafist militant organization based in Iraqi Kurdistan and operating in Syria.
other_designated_names: Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the EU

old_description: Ansar al-Sham, also known as Kataib Ansar al-Sham (Supporters of the Levant), was a Sunni Salafist militant group that aimed to replace the Assad Regime with an Islamic government. The group was formed in 2012 in Syria¬ís Latakia governorate, and became active in Idlib and Aleppo as well. Ansar al-Sham targeted the Assad Regime¬ís forces and sympathizers. However, unlike other former members of the Islamic Front umbrella group, Ansar al-Sham did not oppose the Islamic State. Ansar al-Sham rarely worked alone, and often cooperated with Jabhat Fatah al-Sham, formerly known as Jabhat al-Nusra (Al-Nusra). The group was most known for its participation in a March 2014 offensive in Latakia that was lead by other opposition groups, such as Al-Nusra. After this offensive, Ansar al-Sham had few notable attacks and was mostly engaged in skirmishes with the Syrian army in Latakia. Following a series of skirmishes between opposition groups in the Idlib governorate, Ansar al-Sham joined Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham, formerly known as Jabhat Fatah al-Sham, on February 7, 2017.
description: Ansar al-Sham (also known as Kataib Ansar al-Sham, “Supporters of the Levant Brigade”) was an Islamist opposition group active in the Syrian Civil War.
Notes: old website link

old_description: Ansar al-Shariah in Libya (ASL) is an Islamist militant group that formed in the aftermath of the Libyan uprising against Muammar el-Qaddafi in February 2011. ASL aims to establish a strict implementation of Shariah law in Libya, does not tolerate interpretations of Islam other than its own, and opposes democracy. ASL fights the Libyan government and its armed forces, and at the same time seeks to gain popular support through extensive charitable actions in Libyan communities. In 2013, ASL expanded its operations, effectively occupying territory in Benghazi, Derna, Sirte and Ajdabiya. In February 2015, after the Libyan military targeted Islamist groups during Operation Dignity, ASL lost most of the territory it occupied to Libyan forces. As of March 3, 2016, ASL forces are currently fighting to defend their remaining strongholds in Ajdabiya, Benghazi and Derna.
description: Ansar al-Shariah in Libya (ASL) is a Salafist Islamist militant group that formed in the aftermath of the February 2011 Libyan uprising against Muammar el-Qaddafi.

old_description: Ansar al-Shariah in Tunisia (AST) is a Salafi-Jihadist militant organization established in 2011 that combines community service, proselytization, and violence to promote its Salafi ideology and goals in Tunisia. The group aims to establish Shariah law in Tunisia and promotes the idea of global jihad. The group targets the Tunisian government and armed forces, utilizing a dawa, or charitable works, campaign to gain trust among Tunisian communities. Since its establishment, AST has supported Al Qaeda; however, in July 2014, AST¬ís spokesman, Seifeddine Rais, swore loyalty to IS. description: Ansar al-Shariah in Tunisia (AST) was a Salafi-jihadist militant organization established in 2011 that combined community service, proselytization, and violence to promote its Salafi ideology and goals in Tunisia.

old_description: Ansar al-Sunna Sharia (AS Shariah) is an Iraqi nationalist organization that calls upon all sectors of the Iraqi public to support the end of foreign occupation in Iraq and implement Sharia Law in the nation. The group is speculated to have split from Ansar al-Islam in 2007 over objections to Al Qaeda in Iraqs's targeted killings of civilians. AS Shariah is a member of both the Jihad and Reform Front and the Political Council of Iraqi Resistance.

old_description: Ansar Dine, translated as ¬ìDefenders of the Faith,¬î is an Islamic group founded in December 2011 by Iyad Ag Ghali. The group aims to establish Shariah law across Mali and targets western civilians and peacekeepers. Ansar Dine¬ís ideology closely mirrors that of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) and is reportedly a domestic front group for AQIM, though it has never been publicly recognized by AQIM as an official affiliate. The M-19 was most known for its attacks on multinational corporations and embassies. In 1989, the guerrilla group became a legal political party and became the M-19 Democratic Alliance (AD M-19); the AD M-19 quickly achieved political success but after 1997, lost all political influence, and members gradually abandoned the party and joined the Independent Democratic Pole party and the Alternative Democratic Pole party. old_description: Armed Proletarian Nuclei (NAP) was Southern Italy's most powerful left-wing terrorist organization in the early 1970s. NAP fought against capitalism and promoted a classless society in Italy. The group focused on prisons as the ultimate symbol of state repression and had operational cells both within and outside of prisons. It struck an alliance with the Red Brigades in 1976 and dissolved soon afterward; the Red Brigades absorbed some of its remaining members and assets.
description: Armed Proletarian Nuclei (NAP) was Southern Italy's most powerful left-wing terrorist organization in the early 1970s. NAP fought against capitalism and promoted a classless society in Italy.

old_description: Armed Revolutionary Nuclei (NAR) was the main right-wing terrorist group of the second half of the 1970s. It became active shortly after Italy's "first generation" of right-wing terrorist groups, active from the mid-1950s to the mid-1970s, dissolved with the arrest of many of their members. NAR was perhaps the most active and violent of the neo-fascist groups, carrying out a large number of individual woundings and assassinations as well as claiming responsibility for the worst terrorist bombing in Italian history, which killed 85.
description: Armed Revolutionary Nuclei (NAR) was the largest and most violent right-wing terrorist organization in Italy during the second half of the 1970s.

old_description: Asa¬íib Ahl al-Haq (AAH) is an Iranian-funded Shiite militant and political organization that split off from the Mahdi Army in 2006 under the leadership of Qais al-Khazali. The group is funded by Iran and promotes Iran¬ís interests in Iraq. It primarily targeted U.S. troops prior to the U.S. withdrawal from Iraq in 2011 after which point AAH rebranded itself as a political organization. description: The Asa'ib Ahl al-Haq group is a Shi'a milita group that is funded by Iran and that operates in Iraq and Syria.

old_description: Asian Tigers is a militant group in Pakistan. It is a front of Hakat-ul-Jiahdi-Islami (HuJI) and falls in the umbrella of Tehreek-e-Taliban(TTP) Pakistan. The overall strength of the organization is unknown but it has been reported that the group is a splinter of TTP's Punjabi Taliban. The group is said to be critical over the distinction made within the Taliban ranks of who is considered 'Mujahid' and who is not. Mohammad Omar, alias Usman Punjabi, is the spokesman for the group.
description: Asian Tigers was a group of ethnically Punjabi militants operating in Pakistan that first gained attention in April of 2010.

old_description: The Atomwaffen Division (AWD) is an accelerationist neo-Nazi militant organization operating in the United States with affiliates overseas. The name ¬ìAtomwaffen¬î is German for ¬ìnuclear weapons.¬î AWD promotes the use of violence to overthrow the U.S. government, foment a race war, and establish a new society based on principles of national socialism and white supremacism. old_description: The Azov Battalion is a unit of the Ukrainian National Guard that promotes white supremacy extremism and neo-Nazi beliefs. With the aid of foreign fighters recruited from around the world, Azov has fought against pro-Russian separatists in the eastern half of the country. The group operates a political wing known as the National Corps and cultivates relationships with other extreme-right groups abroad.
description: The Azov Movement is a far-right nationalist network of military, paramilitary, and political organizations based in Ukraine.

group_name: Badr Organization of Reconstruction and Development
old_description: The Badr Organization of Reconstruction and Development, formerly known as the Badr Brigades, is a Shiite militant organization that operates in Iraq and Syria. The Badr Organization advocates for the creation of a separate Shiite region in Southern Iraq and is closely allied with Iran, receiving funding and support from the nation. The Badr Organization was founded as the militia wing of the Islamic Supreme Council of Iraq (ISCI), a Shiite political party that was formerly known as the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution (SCIRI). In 2012, the Badr Organization broke away from the ISCI to maintain ties with Iran after the ISCI attempted to disassociate from the nation.
description: The Badr Organization of Reconstruction and Development, formerly known as the Badr Brigade, is a Shiite militant organization that operates in Iraq and Syria.

The organization was founded in 1964 and fought in the Iranian Balochi Revolt of 1968-1973 and the Independent Balochistan Movement of 1973-1977; in 2003 resurfaced to fight the Pakistani government in the province of Balochistan. The group was founded in 2006 and is mostly comprised of Bugti tribe members and young student political activists. The group uses mortar strikes, car bombs, IEDs, landmines, grenades, small-arms attacks, conventional warfare, unconventional warfare, social media, and nationalist propaganda to achieve its goal of creating an independent Balochi state. The BRA targets Pakistani security forces, Pakistani police, public buses, railways, communication systems, gas pipelines, electricity pylons, check-posts, and civilian offices.
description: The Balochistan Republican Army (BRA) is an ethno-nationalist separatist militant organization fighting against the Pakistani government for an independent Balochi state.

old_description: Bandas Criminales (BACRIM) is a consolidation of criminal gangs that are the successors of the United Self Defense Forces of Colombia (AUC), a right wing paramilitary group. Unlike its predecessor, the AUC, BACRIM has no political motivation and it works closely with leftist guerrilla groups in the drug trade. The Colombian government does not recognize BACRIM as politically legitimate and for this reason, the Colombian government will not hold peace talks with BACRIM leaders.
description: Bandas Criminales (BACRIM) is a drug trafficking, criminal gang that emerged following the demobilization of the United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia (AUC), a paramilitary group, in 2006.

old_description: The Bangsamoro Islamic Freedom Fighters (BIFF), sometimes called the Bangsamoro Islamic Freedom Movement (BIFM), is an Islamic separatist organization based in the southern Philippines. It seeks an independent Islamic state for the Filipino Muslim minority, known as the Moro people, who live primarily in the Philippines¬¨√≠ Mindanao region. The BIFF was founded in 2010 by Ameril Umbra Kato as a splinter group of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF). It has attacked government forces and civilian targets, especially to undermine peace talks between the MILF and the Philippine government.
description: The Bangsamoro Islamic Freedom Fighters is an Islamic separatist organization based in the southern Philippines.

old_description: In 2002, Boko Haram was formed by Mohammad Yusuf as a Sunni Islamist sect that opposed western education and sought to establish an Islamic state in Nigeria. The group has carried out numerous attacks since 2009, including 2011 bombing of the U.N. headquarters in Abuja, but it is best known for the 2014 Chibok schoolgirl kidnapping, when the group abducted over 300 young Nigerian girls from a secular school. Its primary base of operation is northeastern Nigeria, but it has conducted limited operations in Cameroon and Niger. In March 2015, Boko Haram became an affiliate of the Islamic State (IS). In August 2016, IS announced Abu Musab al-Barnawi would assume leadership of Boko Haram. Shekau released statements that Barnawi¬¨√≠s followers were manipulating IS leadership in order to cut him off in a sort of coup; he said that he and his followers would not follow Barnawi, which reportedly led to splits within Boko Haram. It is currently unclear to what extent Shekau or Barnawi has power over Boko Haram militants, but the group remains affiliated with IS.
description: Boko Haram was founded in 2002 as a Sunni Islamist sect with the goals of opposing Western education and establishing an Islamic state in Nigeria.

old_description: The Caucasus Emirate was founded in 2007 by the last President of the Republic of Ichkeria, Doku Umarov. He dissolved the Chechen Republic of Ichkeria in order to create an overarching organization, which would incorporate all the other major and small-scale terrorist groups in the North Caucasus. The Caucasus Emirate has maintained strong ties with Al Qaeda and the Taliban. They allow training camps in the North Caucasus and send fighters to train in Al Qaeda-sponsored training camps.

old_description: The Chechen Republic of Ichkeria was founded after the collapse of the Soviet Union. The aim of the Republic was to establish an independent Chechnya under Shariah. In order to achieve this goal they worked with other terrorist groups in the North Caucasus to fight the Russian Federation. The group was absorbed into the Caucasus Emirate upon its formation in 2007.
description: The Chechen Republic of Ichkeria (CRI) was a moderate Islamic secessionist government operating in Chechnya from 1991 until 2007. Its goal was to create an alternative governing body to the Russian regime.

description: The Communist Party of the Philippines - New People's Army (CPP-NPA) seeks to overthrow the Philippine government in favor of a new state led by the working class and to expel U.S. influence from the Philippines. Formed in 1968, it has historically focused on building support among the rural peasantry, although it has operated throughout the Philippines. While it peaked in size and influence in the 1970s and 1980s, the CPP-NPA still engages in significant levels of violence and is the world's oldest existing Communist insurgency.

old_description: The Eelam Revolutionary Organization of Students (EROS) was one of the original separatist groups in Sri Lanka fighting for an independent Tamil state. EROS was founded in 1975 and acted initially as a think-tank researching Tamil issues. Soon thereafter, its leaders established ties with terrorist groups in the Middle East and Africa, such as the Palestinian Liberation Organization (PLO) and the African National Congress (ANC). EROS also organized the first terrorist training camps in Sri Lanka. EROS was the least violent and militarily active of the Tamil militant groups of the 1980s, although the group was responsible for a series of bombings in the mid-1980s and the kidnapping of a British journalist. As other Tamil groups began to emerge, EROS slowly lost its influence in the community. Eventually, the majority of EROS members defected to the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE). EROS ceased to be a militant movement when Shankar Rajee formed the EROS political party.
description: The Eelam Revolutionary Organization of Students (EROS) was one of the original separatist groups in Sri Lanka fighting for an independent Tamil state.

old_description: The Egyptian Islamic Group (EIJ) was a militant Islamist organization founded in 1979 as a splinter of the Muslim Brotherhood. It is most famous for its 1981 assassination of Egyptian President Anwar Sadat and for its close ties to Al Qaeda. The group originated in Egypt, but following a crackdown by the Egyptian government, many of the group¬¨√≠s members emigrated first to Afghanistan, then to Sudan, and eventually back to Afghanistan. Although initially the EIJ sought to overthrow the Egyptian government and establish an Islamic state in its stead, as the EIJ grew more intertwined with Al Qaeda, it reoriented to focus on global Jihad against the West. The EIJ¬¨√≠s most famous leader was Aymenn al-Zawahiri, who became Osama bin Laden¬¨√≠s second in command in Al Qaeda after the EIJ merged into Al Qaeda in 1998.
description: The Egyptian Islamic Jihad (EIJ), often known as al-Jihad or the Jihad group, was a Jihadi, Salafi militant organization founded in Egypt in 1979 by Muhammad 'Abd al-Salam Farraj.

old_description: The Groupe Islamique Arm√©, or the Armed Islamic Group, best known by its French acronym (GIA), was an Islamist extremist group based in Algeria and formed by militants who fought in the war in Afghanistan. The group was founded in January 1992 in response to the Algerian military coup, which canceled an election in which the Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) was likely to win. The GIA sought to overthrow the Algerian government and establish an Islamic state ruled by Shariah law. The group quickly gained notoriety as Algeria¬ís most dangerous extremist group for its indiscriminate targeting of civilians and its 1992 campaign of high-profile terrorist attacks. In its most active period, in the mid 1990s, the group established a presence in France, Belgium, Italy and Britain, as well as its native Algeria. The GIA¬ís most known attacks included its hijacking of an Air France flight in Algiers in December 1994, a series of subway bombings in Paris in 1995, and a campaign of Algerian village massacres in the late 1990s. In 1998, the GIA became divided over the issue of attacking civilians, and a group of militants, lead by Hassan Hattab, split to form the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat (GSPC). Many GIA members eventually defected to join the GSPC or Al Qaeda. The group reportedly stopped operating in 2004, after the majority of its leadership was arrested or killed.
description: Groupe Islamique Armé (GIA) was an Islamic extremist militant organization operating in Algeria.

old_description: Hamas Iraq is an Iraqi Sunni Islamist organization that broke away from the 1920s Revolution Brigades in March 2007. The group primarily targeted U.S. forces in Iraq from 2007-2011. In July 2007, Hamas Iraq joined with several of Iraq¬ís largest insurgent groups to form an umbrella organization called the Political Council for Iraqi Resistance (PCIR).
description: Hamas Iraq was an Iraqi Sunni Islamist organization that broke away from the 1920s Revolution Brigades in March 2007.

old_description: The Haqqani Network (HN) is a Sunni Islamist militant organization operating in the southeastern region of Afghanistan and the northwestern Federally Administered Tribal Areas in Pakistan. HN was founded by Mujahideen commander Jalaluddin Haqqani in the late 1970s, and rose to prominence in the anti-Soviet war in the 1980s. The core structure of HN is largely familial and hierarchical. HN¬¨√≠s primary goals are to expel foreign forces, increase influence over new territory, and restore Taliban rule. HN employs a variety of tactics including violence, co-option, and infiltration of local security forces and government structures to consolidate its power and support Taliban, Al Qaeda, and other state and non-state actors.
description: The Haqqani Network (HN) is an insurgent group that operates in the Southeastern region of Afghanistan and the Northwestern Federally Administered Tribal Areas in Pakistan.

old_description: Harakat-ul-Mujahedeen (HuM) is a Pakistani militant group that split from Harkat-ul-Jihad-al-Islami (HuJI) in 1985. The group¬¨√≠s main goals are to establish Islamic, Pakistani rule of the disputed Kashmir and Jammu region, carry out attacks against India, and wage war against U.S.-led coalition forces in Afghanistan. To achieve these objectives, HuM employs various methods, including bombings, hijackings, kidnappings and executions of Indian soldiers, government officials, civilians, and foreign tourists. HuM has allegedly received support from Pakistan¬¨√≠s Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI) since its formation. The group is one of the oldest and closest allies of Al Qaeda. It also has links to Hizbul Mujahideen, Lashkar-e-Taiba (LeT), Jaish-e-Muhammad (JeM), Lashkar-e-Jhangvi (LeJ), Sipah e Sahaba Pakistan (SSP), and the religious political party, Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam Samiul Haq (JUI-S). description: Harakat-ul-Mujahedeen (HuM) is a Pakistani militant group that split from Harkat-ul-Jihad-al-Islami (HuJI) in 1985.

old_description: Harkat-ul-Jihad al-Islami (HuJI) is a Pakistan-based Deobandi militant group with the central aim of liberating Jammu and Kashmir from India and making them part of Pakistan. The group was founded in 1984 during the Soviet-Afghan war and is currently led by Qari Saifullah Akhtar. HuJI has ties to both the Taliban and Al Qaeda, as well as to numerous other Pakistani-based militant organizations. HuJI has been responsible for a number of small and large-scale bombings and assassinations, particularly in the Indo-Pak region, and has an active affiliate in Bangladesh.

old_description: Hay¬¨√≠at Tahrir al-Sham (Tahrir al-Sham), formerly known as Jabhat al-Nusra (Al-Nusra), is a Sunni opposition group that aims to overthrow the Assad Regime and establish an Islamic Emirate in Syria. The group targets the Assad Regime, Shiite forces and U.S backed forces in 11 of Syria¬¨√≠s 13 governorates and has conducted operations in Lebanon¬¨√≠s Bekka Valley. Al-Nusra was formed in late 2011, when Al Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) emir Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi sent AQI operative Abu Muhammad al-Julani to Syria to organize regional jihadist cells. At its inception, Al-Nusra began harboring the Khorasan Group, a cell of approximately two-dozen experienced Al Qaeda (AQ) jihadists who were sent to Syria by central AQ leadership in order to develop international terror plots. However Al-Nusra began targeting the Islamic State (IS, formerly AQI) in January 2014 amid rising tensions between IS and the Sunni opposition forces. Additionally in July 2016, Al-Nusra ended its affiliation with Al Qaeda (AQ) and changed its name to Jabhat Fatah al-Sham (The Front for the Conquest of the Levant). Throughout the conflict, the group has sought to cast itself as an irreplaceable military ally for opposition forces, and has a longstanding military partnership with Ahrar al-Sham.
description: Hay’at Tahrir al-Sham, formerly known as Jabhat al-Nusra (Al-Nusra), is a Sunni opposition group that aims to overthrow the Assad Regime and establish an Islamic Emirate in Syria.

old_description: Hezbollah is a Shiite political and militant organization based in Lebanon. Since its creation in the 1980s, it has evolved into a hybrid organization woven into the structure of Lebanese society through social services and active participation in politics while also carrying out international terrorist attacks and regional military operations. The ICU evolved from a judicial system to a governing apparatus, eventually providing social services and implementing Shariah law in the territories under its control. The ICU maintained a powerful militia, which included the group that would be called Al Shabaab, and conquered Mogadishu as well as much of Somalia in June 2006. old_description: Jaysh al-Islam (The Islam Army, The Islam Brigade) is a Syrian opposition group that aims to depose the Assad Regime. The group was formed in 2013 through a merger of about fifty Damascus-based opposition groups, and was initially lead by former Liwa al-Islam commander Zahran Alloush. The group operates in the Homs, Aleppo, Idlib, Hama, Daraa, and Quneitra governorates, and was an active member of the Islamic Front umbrella organization until the Islamic Front dissolved in 2014. Jaysh al-Islam opposes the Islamic State (IS) and has been battling the group since July 2014 when it first ousted IS from Eastern Ghouta in Damascus. Jaysh al-Islam has also had a tense relationship with former Al Qaeda affiliate Jabhat Fatah al-Sham, formerly known as Jabhat al-Nusra (Al-Nusra), ever since Al-Nusra rejected the authority of Jaysh al-Islam¬ís Unified Judiciary Council court system. Through late 2015 and early 2016, Jaysh al-Islam¬ís deteriorating ties with Al-Nusra and a series of other controversies have fueled political unrest in Eastern Ghouta.

It was formed by Izzat Ibrihim al-Douri in 2006 in response to the execution of Saddam Hussein. With Hussein¬ís death, many of Iraq¬ís remaining Baathists coalesced around Douri, the most senior remaining Ba¬íathist leader in the country, forming the basis of the JRTN. The group has since expanded to become one of the most powerful insurgent organizations in Iraq, second only to the Islamic State (IS). It originated in the late 1980s and was responsible for a number of high-profile attacks that mainly targeted Christians and Western interests throughout the 1990s and early 2000s, including the 2002 Bali nightclub bombings that killed over 200. old_description: Jund al-Aqsa was initially led by Shiekh Abdul Aziz al-Qatari as a subunit within Al Qaeda¬ís (AQ) Syrian affiliate, Jabhat al-Nusra (Al-Nusra). In response to tension between Al-Nusra and the Islamic State (IS), Jund al-Aqsa left Al-Nusra in September 2013 in order to provide an alternate front to recruit reserve foreign fighters. Although the group left Al-Nusra in 2013, Jund al-Aqsa continued to affirm its allegiance to Al-Nusra and AQ central command, and was active predominantly in Syria¬ís Idlib and Hama governorates. In addition to direct cooperation with Al-Nusra, Jund al-Aqsa coordinated attacks with the group as part of the Jaysh al-Fatah umbrella organization until October 2015, when it left the group due to misgivings about the tactics employed by Ahrar al-Sham and fighting IS. Jund al-Aqsa began coordinating attacks against the Syrian army with IS in early 2016, but still remained loyal to AQ and Al-Nusra, now known as Jabhat Fatah al-Sham (Fatah al-Sham). Jund al-Aqsa also had a tense relationship with Ahrar al-Sham, a Salafi group that began targeting Jund al-Aqsa in October 2016. On October 10, 2016, Jund al-Aqsa merged into Fatah al-Sham, and Fatah al-Sham leaders negotiated a ceasefire with Ahrar al-Sham.

old_description: Kata¬íib Hezbollah (KH), also known as the Hezbollah Brigades, is a Shiite Iraqi insurgent group in Iraq and Syria that was founded in 2007. The group is led by Abu Mahdi al-Muhandis and receives large amounts of training, logistical support, and weapons from the Iranian Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps (IRGC). From 2007-2011, KH directed the majority of its attacks against U.S.-Coalition forces in Iraq and was designated as a foreign terrorist organization by the U.S. on July 2, 2009. Following the U.S. withdrawal from Iraq in 2011, KH sent large numbers of its fighters to Syria to fight alongside Hezbollah and the Assad government. KH has also deployed its troops in Iraq to fight the Islamic State (IS) and is a member of the Popular Mobilization Forces (PMF), an umbrella group of Shiite militant groups fighting IS in Iraq.

It has declared the U.S., Israel and India as existential enemies of Islam. LeT has conducted numerous deadly attacks against Indian officials, troops, and civilians in the disputed area of Kashmir as well as throughout India and Afghanistan. The group maintains training camps, facilities, schools, and medical clinics in Pakistan. It runs its own charitable organization, Jamaat-ud-Dawa (JUD), and has supported humanitarian relief missions in Pakistan. In 2002, Pakistan officially banned Lashkar-e-Taiba. old_description: The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) were a militant separatist group fighting for an independent homeland for Hindu Tamils in Northeastern Sri Lanka. The LTTE was founded in the early 1970s by Velupillai Prabhakaran, who led the group until his death by Sri Lankan armed forces in May 2009. During the 1980s, the LTTE defeated a number of different Tamil militant groups, emerging as the dominant group by the end of the decade. The LTTE successfully carried out a number of high-profile attacks, including the assassination of two heads of state. The LTTE were also notorious for their use of suicide terrorism, perpetrated by their elite suicide bombing unit known as the Black Tigers. Starting in 1985, the LTTE began negotiations with the Sri Lankan government; however, multiple rounds of negotiations failed and were interrupted by bouts of violence and clashes between both sides. In March 2004, a large faction of the LTTE led by Colonel Karuna defected, significantly weakening the organization. In 2006, after another failed round of negotiations, the Sri Lankan government declared all-out war on the LTTE and the group was militarily defeated in May 2009.

The group announced its official existence in 1995 and was led by Abdelhakim Belhadj. The group was most active in the eastern Libyan region of Cyrenaica and was known for assassination attempts against Qaddafi, helping plan bombings in Morocco in 2003, and violent clashes with the Benghazi police. The LIFG was allegedly tied to Al Qaeda and had hostile relations with the Group Islamique Arme (GIA). In the late 1990s, the LIFG lost strength after repeated military campaigns against them by the Qaddafi regime and disbanded in 2010.

It was active in the provinces of Homs, Idlib, and Raqqa. While Liwa al-Haqq only engaged in one documented attack, it was an active member of the Syrian Islamic Front (SIF) umbrella organization, which was founded in 2012, and was also affiliated with the Free Syrian Army (FSA).¬†However, Liwa al-Haqq left both groups after joining the Islamic Front umbrella organization in November 2013. After joining the Islamic Front, Liwa al-Haqq commander Sheikh Abu Rateb served as the organization¬ís general secretary until the Islamic Front dissolved in mid-2014 due to disagreements between two of its largest founding members, Ahrar al-Sham and Jaysh al-Islam. Although Liwa al-Haqq allegedly merged with Ahrar al-Sham after the Islamic Front dissolved, some reports indicate that Liwa al-Haqq may still be acting autonomously, and it is listed as an independent member of the Jaysh al-Fatah umbrella organization.

old_description: Liwa al-Tawhid (the Tawhid Brigade) was an Aleppo-based militant group that was formed by several small opposition brigades to fight the Assad Regime in July 2012. The group¬ís goal was to replace the Assad Regime with a moderate Islamic state that had a basis in Shariah law, but included civilian rule, elections, and protection for minorities. Liwa al-Tawhid rose to prominence in July 2012 after becoming one of the first opposition groups to control territory in Aleppo. It was initially considered a member of the Free Syrian Army (FSA) and participated in the FSA-linked Syrian Islamic Front umbrella organization from January 2013 until November 2013, when Liwa al-Tawhid joined the Islamic Front umbrella group. Liwa al-Tawhid also cooperated with the Islamic State (IS) until January 2014, when it began targeting IS and temporarily drove IS out of the city of Aleppo. In July 2014, Liwa al-Tawhid, Ahrar al-Sham, and other former members of the Islamic Front, which dissolved in mid-2014, agreed to merge their Aleppo-based fighters and operate under the name Islamic Front. Since this merger, there have been conflicting reports on if Liwa al-Tawhid is still conducting operations independently.

old_description: The Mahdi Army, also known as the Jaysh al-Mahdi (JAM), is a Shiite militia led by Muqtada al-Sadr. The group was founded in 2003 and was considered one of the most dangerous groups in Iraq until early 2008. In March 2008, the Iraqi Security Forces and coalition troops launched a major offensive against the Mahdi Army in Basra, significantly undermining its capacity. After signing a ceasefire agreement with the coalition forces in 2008, Sadr reoriented the Mahdi Army to focus on social services provision for the Shiite community. In 2010, Sadr again redirected the focus of many members of the Mahdi army, this time to the upcoming parliamentary elections, before stepping out of the public eye in 2013. Then in June 2014, he reemerged to revive the Mahdi Army, now called the Peace Brigades, in order to join the fight against the Islamic State.

old_description: The Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) is the largest militant organization in the Philippines, and it seeks autonomy for Filipino Muslims. The MILF split from the Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) in 1977, although it was generally inactive and did not call itself the MILF until 1984. The MILF controls territory in the southern Philippines, governing with Shariah law. It has generally focused on political negotiation, but it has a significant history of terrorism and militancy. In 2014, the MILF concluded peace negotiations with the Philippine government for an autonomous region in the southern Philippines, to be called the Bangsamoro. The MILF is in the process of gradual disarmament.
description: The Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) is the largest militant organization in the Philippines and seeks autonomy for Filipino Muslims.

old_description: The Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) is an Islamic separatist organization based in the southern Philippines that seeks autonomy for Filipino Muslims, called Moros. The MNLF was established in 1972, and it led the Moro separatist movement until the 1996 Final Peace Agreement between the MNLF and the Philippine government. Since 1996, the MNLF has been surpassed in strength and influence by its rival group, the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF), which began its own peace talks with the Philippine government. Today, the MNLF consists of many factions, some of which support current negotiations between the Philippine government and the MILF.
description: The Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) is an Islamic separatist organization based in the southern Philippines that seeks autonomy for Filipino Muslims, called Moros.

old_description: The Moroccan Islamic Combatant Group (GICM) is an Islamic militant group established in the mid- to late-1990's. Like many other armed Islamic movements formed at the time, the GICM was inspired by the mujahideen in Afghanistan, where some of GICM's members fought against the Soviet Union. At one point, the group was considered to have several cells in Europe that financed much of the group's activities in Morocco. The group was founded by a faction split from Morrocan group Shabaab Islamiyah. Despite having participated in several successful attacks, such as the 2003 Casablanca bombings and the 2004 Madrid bombings, the group is now considered to be extremely weak or dissolved. The Moroccan government has conducted a successful counterterrorism campaign that has killed or imprisoned many of the group's leaders. Some believe former members may have simply joined other similar groups.
description: The Moroccan Islamic Combatant Group (GICM) was a Sunni Islamist militant organization operating in Morocco, North Africa and Western Europe.

old_description: The Nazir Group is a faction of the Pakistani Taliban that operates in South Waziristan. Although it is unknown precisely when the group formed, it first gained prominence in 2006, when its original leader, Maulvi Nazir, received the support of the Pakistani Taliban under Mullah Dadullah and the approval of the Taliban Shura. The Nazir Group's primary focus is on combatting U.S.-led coalition forces and the governments of Afghanistan and Pakistan. The group aligns itself with Al Qaeda and embraces the philosophy of global jihad. The group is currently active under the leadership of Bahawal Khan, and operates primarily in Wana, South Waziristan and the Afghanistan-Pakistan region.

old_description: The New IRA is a republican paramilitary group that formed in 2012. The group resulted from the merger of the Real IRA, Republican Action Against Drugs (RAAD), and several smaller dissident republican groups. In 2019, many former members of ONH2 also joined the New IRA. Like most republican groups, the New IRA¬ís primary goals are to oppose the non-violent peace process in Northern Ireland and push for the unification of Ireland. The group regularly targets police units and has killed several officers through its attacks. The New IRA has also steadily increased its bombing campaign in Northern Ireland, most recently setting a car bomb off beside a courthouse in Derry. In April 2019, the New IRA mistakenly shot and killed protestant journalist Lyra McKee during a riot. Despite the significant backlash after the event, the group continued to remain operational after the murder. Brexit has also reportedly increased the appeal of the group to young disenfranchised republicans. The New IRA is considered to be the most deadly militant group active in Northern Ireland today.
description: The New Irish Republican Army is a republican dissident militant organization operating in Northern Ireland.

old_description: The right-wing New Order (ON) was the first major terrorist group to emerge in Italy after World War II. It was a militant offshoot of right-wing parliamentary party Italian Social Movement (MSI). It sought to overthrow Italian democracy and reinstate a fascist regime. It spawned other neo-fascist terrorist groups, notably National Vanguard (AN), and along with AN and National Front (FN), it was one of the three main neo-fascist terrorist groups in post-World War II Italy. ON, AN, and FN had deep ties; their membership overlapped and they frequently collaborated on attacks, most notably an aborted coup attempt in 1970. ON dissolved when it was banned in the mid-1970s, and was thereafter subsumed into Black Order along with remnants of FN and AN.
description: The New Order was a right-wing militant organization based in Italy that sought to overthrow Italy's democracy and reinstate a fascist regime.

old_description: Oath Keepers is a far-right militant organization operating in the United States. With a focus on recruiting former military and law enforcement personnel, the group seeks to protect Americans from what it perceives as violations of U.S. citizens¬í natural rights by the U.S. federal government. The group¬ís name refers to the oath to ¬ìdefend the Constitution against all enemies, foreign and domestic¬î that is sworn by members of the military and police. Founded in 2009, Oath Keepers (OK) is one of the largest and most prominent organizations of the militia/patriot movement and includes chapters across the country. It is not a white supremacist organization. Members of the group draw heavily on historical memory of the American Revolution, portraying themselves as the heirs of the Founding Fathers and the federal government as a modern-day colonial Great Britain. The group is known for participating in armed standoffs with federal agents in the western United States. In 2016, OK aligned itself with the administration of President Donald Trump and in opposition to the anti-fascist (antifa) movement. OK is politically active, and several members of the organization were elected to public office on the state and local levels. The group played a major role in the storming of the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021, to prevent the certification of Joe Biden¬ís victory in the 2020 presidential election.
description: Oath Keepers is a far-right militant organization operating in the United States that recruits former military and law enforcement personnel.

It was based in Genoa beginning in 1969 and never expanded geographically and never attracted more than a few dozen followers. It was absorbed by Partisan Action Groups (GAP) after most of its members were arrested; GAP was in turn absorbed by the Red Brigades.

old_description: The Official Irish Republican Army (OIRA) is one of two splinter groups that broke away from the Irish Republican Army (IRA) in 1969 (the other being the Provisional Irish Republican Army (PIRA)). OIRA was by far the less violent of the two IRA offshoots, initially intending to lead a defensive united class struggle and avoid militant republicanism. It conducted mostly small attacks against British forces in an effort to unite and free Northern Ireland from England. OIRA declared a ceasefire in 1972, after which its violent activity dropped off dramatically, with most of its members becoming involved in socialist politics through the Workers' Party. The organization continued to stage isolated attacks at least until 1979, however, and did not fully decommission its weapons until February 2010.

old_description: The Order of Nine Angles (O9A or ONA) is a satanist neo-Nazi organization active in the United Kingdom. The group valorizes Hitler and champions the transgression of moral norms, including calling for rape and murder. Ultimately, O9A seeks to weaken society and replace it with a new civilization based on principles of fascism and satanism.  O9A practices religious rituals in worship of Hitler and Nazism, which involve sexual acts and sacrifice (human or animal). Founded in the 1970s and originally based in the UK, O9A today operates decentralized networks active around the world.  British far-right extremist David Myatt reportedly started the group. Myatt allegedly leads O9A under the pseudonym Anton Long and writes most of its texts.  Given O9A¬ís secretive nature, accurate size estimates are difficult to assess and range from fewer than 50 members to over 2,000 worldwide.
description: The Order of Nine Angles (O9A or ONA) is a satanist neo-Nazi organization active in the United Kingdom.

old_description: GAP was one of the earliest left-wing terrorist groups in Italy. It was small and short-lived and was best-known for its leader, Giangiacomo Feltrinelli, a wealthy publisher who feared a fascist takeover of Italy and sought to recreate World War II-era communist resistance. The group ended with Feltrinelli's accidental death while planting an explosive; its remaining members were absorbed into the Red Brigades.

old_description: The People's Liberation Organization of Tamil Eelam (PLOTE) was a militant Tamil separatist group fighting for an independent Tamil homeland in northeastern Sri Lanka. The group was founded by a former LTTE member and the two groups continued to clash until the military defeat of the LTTE in 2009. In the 1980s, PLOTE enjoyed the support of the Indian intelligence services (RAW); however, the group reached its military peak in 1985. Afterwards, RAW withdrew their support, and the LTTE launched a major offensive against PLOTE, causing the majority of its members to defect to the LTTE or be killed. Today, the PLOTE is a minor political party and small paramilitary force.
description: The People's Liberation Organization of Tamil Eelam was a militant Tamil separatist group fighting for an independent Tamil homeland in northeastern Sri Lanka.

old_description: The Popular Liberation Army (EPL) was a Marxist guerrilla group that formed in 1967 as the armed wing of the Communist Party of Colombia (Marxist-Leninist), a splinter party of the Colombian Communist Party (PCC). The EPL openly used the drug trade to finance its operations in an attempt to achieve its goal of protecting the proletariat from government influence. In 1991, less than half of the group demobilized and transformed itself into a political party while the majority of members continued militant activities as a dissident group under the leadership of Megateo, originally the leader of one of EPL¬ís factions, the Libardo Mora Toro Front.

old_description: Prima Linea was Italy's second-largest left-wing terrorist group after the Red Brigades, with nearly a thousand members. The PL sought to overthrow the capitalist state in Italy and replace it with a dictatorship of the proletariat. The organization targeted mostly politicians, law enforcement, factory managers, and business leaders. PL was loosely organized, with a national leadership coordinating several local cells. These cells determined local tactics largely independently and staged attacks under a variety of names. It had members throughout Italy but was most active in the industrial cities of the north. The group split into factions and ultimately dissolved after the arrest of several of its members.

old_description: The Proud Boys (PB) are a U.S. white supremacist, misogynistic, and anti-Muslim extremist group active in the alt-right movement. The organization is known for its participation in demonstrations around the country, such as the August 2017 ¬ìUnite the Right Rally,¬î which the group co-organized.  In 2017, the Proud Boys established a paramilitary wing known as the Fraternal Order of the Alt-Knights (FOAK) with the goal of defending right-wing extremists at rallies. In August 2017, Rewire estimated that the Proud Boys number about 6,000 members online, though the number of active members is unclear. Though the Proud Boys cultivate ties with groups that have neo-Nazi affiliations, PB resists the neo-Nazi label and its connotations for themselves. The group has caught attention for its leading part in the U.S. Capitol riots on January 6, 2021, in which a mob sought to block Joe Biden's presidential election victory.

old_description: The Ras Kamboni Brigade was an Islamist militia operating primarily in Jubaland, located in southern Somalia near the border with Kenya. It was founded sometime in the 2000s by Hassan Abdullah Hersi al-Turki, a former leader in an Islamist group called Al Ittihad Al Islamiya (AIAI) and its successor, the Islamic Courts Union (ICU). The Ras Kamboni Brigade fought against Somalia¬¨√≠s Transitional Federal Government (TFG) and foreign troops. In 2009, the group briefly merged with three other Islamist militant groups to form a new organization, Hizbul Islam. However, over the course of late 2009 and early 2010, the Ras Kamboni Brigade broke away from Hizbul Islam. The group split into two factions; one faction, led by al-Turki, joined Al Shabaab, and the other faction formed a new group, the Ras Kamboni Movement.

old_description: The Ras Kamboni Movement is an Islamist militia based in southern Somalia that emerged as a splinter group of the Ras Kamboni Brigade in 2010. Since its appearance as an independent group, the Ras Kamboni Movement has been led by Ahmed Mohamed Islam, better known as ¬¨√¨Madobe.¬¨√Æ The Ras Kamboni Movement¬¨√≠s main rival is Al Shabaab, another Islamist militant organization in Somalia, and the two groups have fought for control of various areas in southern Somalia, especially the major port city of Kismayo. The Ras Kamboni Movement has held de facto control of Kismayo since 2012, although it has continued to fight other militias seeking to control the city. old_description: The Real Irish Republican Army (rIRA) was the most violent of the groups to split from the Provisional Irish Republican Army (PIRA) in protest over the PIRA's ceasefires and participation in the peace process. The rIRA split from PIRA in 1997 and aimed to force a British withdrawal from Northern Ireland and unify Northern and Southern Ireland. Among its targets were British soldiers, Northern Ireland police forces, and civilians. Within a year of forming, rIRA staged the bloodiest attack of the modern Northern Ireland conflict with a car bombing in the town of Omagh in August 1998 that killed 29. In the face of public outrage over the attack, the rIRA declared a ceasefire a month later. The group resumed attacks in England and Northern Ireland in 2000. While the Real IRA has not mounted a large-scale attack since 1998, it engaged in hundreds of smaller attacks throughout the twenty-first century, including bombings, shootings, kidnappings, and more. During this time, the group declined due to widespread arrests and did not carry out a fatal attack since killing two British soldiers in 2009. In 2012, the Real IRA merged with three other dissident Republican groups to form the New IRA.
description: The Real Irish Republican Army (IRA) is a republican dissident militant organization operating in Northern Ireland.

The group sought to defend against a feared fascist coup and sought to overthrow the democratic Italian government and replace it with a dictatorship of the proletariat. It absorbed many smaller groups before finally splitting up itself in the face of widespread arrests and internal disputes beginning in 1980.

Like the BR and its other successors, it sought to overthrow the capitalist state in Italy and replace it with a dictatorship of the proletariat, and its specific demands included Italy's withdrawal from NATO. The BR-PCC inherited the core of the BR and was the most active and successful of the BR's successors. It lasted the longest and carried out the highest-profile attacks. Like the BR and its other successors, the BR-PCC declined due to arrests, and dissolved when some of its imprisoned leaders declared the armed struggle finished.

old_description: The Rise Above Movement (RAM), founded in 2017 as the DIY Division, is a white supremacist militant organization based in southern California. With ties to the U.S. skinhead movement, RAM operates essentially as a street-fighting club. Members train in mixed martial arts in order to physically assault their opponents, commonly at political rallies, protests, and demonstrations. The group has cultivated ties with white supremacist groups in the United States and overseas, most notably with the Azov Battalion in Ukraine. RAM considers itself a part of the alt-right and promotes white supremacism, anti-Semitism, and xenophobia.

old_description: The Russian Imperial Movement (RIM) is an extreme-right, white supremacist militant organization based in St. Petersburg, Russia. Founded in 2002, the group promotes ethnic Russian nationalism, advocates the restoration of Russia¬ís tsarist regime, and seeks to fuel white supremacy extremism in the West. RIM maintains contacts with neo-Nazi and white supremacist groups across Europe and the United States. The group has provided paramilitary training to Russian nationals and members of like-minded organizations from other countries at its facilities in St. Petersburg. Members of RIM¬ís armed wing, the Imperial Legion, have fought alongside pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine and been involved in conflicts in Libya and Syria. In addition to its ultra-nationalist beliefs, RIM is known for its anti-Semitic and anti-Ukrainian views. The U.S. State Department listed RIM as a Specially Designated Global Terrorist (SDGT) in April 2020. It is the first white supremacist group to be designated as a SDGT.

The SSU had been a military brigade in the Islamic Movement of Kurdistan (IMK) before splitting off to form an independent group in 1998. In 2001, the SSU merged with two other Kurdish Sunni groups to form Jund al-Islam, a group that would became a founding member of Ansar al-Islam later that year.

old_description: The Sipah-e-Sahaba Pakistan (SSP) was founded with state support in 1985 and has since been the dominant anti-Shiite religious-political organization in Pakistan. Using politics and sectarian violence, the SSP aims to conform Pakistani society to its rigid interpretation of Deobandi Islam. The group's offshoot, Lashkar-e-Jhangvi (LeJ), serves as an ultra-violent faction of the same movement, and the two have long-standing ties to other militant groups, including al Qaeda. SSP and LeJ's growing links to the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) have led some analysts to consider some of their members to be part of an umbrella group called the Punjabi Taliban, named after the groups' traditional base and where they retain ties to the provincial government.

old_description: The Special Purpose Islamic Regiment was founded in 1996 by Chechen separatist Arbi Barayev. The mission of the group was to establish an independent Chechnya under Shariah. They worked with the other terrorist groups in the North Caucasus like the Chechen Republic of Ichkeria, the Special Purpose Islamic Regiment, and the International Islamic Peacekeeping Brigade to lead joint operations against the Russian Federation. Like the other groups in the area they received financial assistance from Al Qaeda. The group was absorbed into the Caucasus Emirate upon its formation in 2007.

old_description: Suqour al-Sham was a Syrian opposition group that sought to replace the Assad Regime with an Islamic State. Ahmad Abu Eissa founded the group in Syria¬ís Idlib governorate after his brothers were killed in armed civilian clashes with the Assad Regime in 2011. Through a series of mergers with smaller brigades, Suqour al-Sham quickly became one of the most powerful local opposition groups. Suqour al-Sham was active in multiple Syrian opposition coalitions, including the FSA linked Syrian Islamic Liberation Front (SILF) umbrella organization. However, the group began to distance itself from the FSA in 2013, and joined the Islamic Front umbrella group in November 2013. Although it was once one of the strongest groups in the Islamic Front, Suqour al-Sham¬ís strength declined after two of its most prominent brigades defected in order to avoid fighting the Islamic State (IS) and after IS assassinated Suqour al-Sham¬ís military commander. Suqour al-Sham signed a ceasefire with IS in February 2014, and after the dissolution of the Islamic Front in mid-2014, the group continued to coordinate intermittent attacks against the Assad Regime with Ahrar al-Sham and Al Qaeda affiliate Jabhat al-Nusra (Al-Nusra). In March 2015, Suqour al-Sham merged in to Ahrar al-Sham.
description: Suqour al-Sham was founded as an opposition militant organization in Syria. It is currently active as part of the Turkish-aligned National Liberation Front (NLF).

old_description: The Tamil Eelam Liberation Organization (TELO) is a militant organization that fought for an independent homeland for Sri Lanka¬ís Tamils. TELO, which was officially founded in 1977, first entered into a cooperative alliance with the LTTE, as both were driven by the same fundamental goals. After the death of its co-founders in 1983, TELO¬ís new leader Sri Sabaratnam reached out to RAW and established close ties with the external unit of the Indian Intelligence Services. With Indian funding, TELO grew in both numbers and capabilities. However, in April 1986, LTTE launched a full-out assault on TELO, which it now perceived as a moderate group. By May, the LTTE had successfully killed several hundred TELO cadres, as well as Sabaratnam. With little leadership structure and an over-reliance on Indian support, the organization was never able to re-emerge as a militant group. In 1987, TELO officially disbanded as a military organization and transitioned to a political party.
description: The Tamil Eelam Liberation Organization (TELO) was a militant organization that fought for an independent homeland for Sri Lanka’s Tamils.

old_description: The Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) is the largest and deadliest militant umbrella organization in Pakistan. The TTP formed under Baitullah Mehsud in 2007. It is a subset of the Pakistani Taliban, which includes most, but not all, of the Pakistani Taliban groups. The organization is closely linked to Al Qaeda, and is also associated with the Afghan Taliban. However, unlike the Afghan Taliban, which focuses on combatting U.S.-led coalition forces in Afghanistan, the TTP focuses on combatting Pakistani security forces. The TTP is based in South Waziristan and has three central goals: to enforce Shariah law in Pakistan; to establish a unified front to combat U.S.-led coalition forces in Afghanistan; and to conduct defensive jihad against Pakistani security forces. Ultimately, the group also seeks to overthrow the Pakistani government and establish an Islamic caliphate in Pakistan. Since 2014, internal splits and Pakistani counterterrorism operations have weakened the TTP. The group remains active under the leadership of Maulana Fazlullah.
description: The Tehrik-i-Taliban is the largest militant organization in Pakistan that operates under the larger umbrella of the Pakistani Taliban.
Notes: unclear state sponsors

old_description: The Base is an accelerationist neo-Nazi group operating mostly in the United States and Canada. The group¬ís founder is based in Russia. Organized mostly online as a loose network of cells, the Base anticipates the overthrow of modern society and an ensuing race war. The group¬ís objective is to establish a white ethno-state in North America, inspired by the separatist projects of other U.S. white supremacist groups, such as the Northwest Front and Aryan Nations. As of November 2020, the Base had successfully carried out acts of vandalism, but its major attacks against human targets were foiled by law enforcement. The group regularly holds offline meet-ups and paramilitary training sessions for its members across the United States. Although this organization¬ís name appears to be an English translation of ¬ìAl Qaeda,¬î the Base claims no affiliation with the jihadist group. The FBI infiltrated the Base in 2019 and arrested many of its members between late 2019 and early 2020. In January 2020, it was reported that the Base¬ís founder, a U.S. citizen named Rinaldo Nazzaro, led the group from his residence in St. Petersburg, Russia.

old_description: The Islamic State (IS) also known as the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) and The Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) is a Salafi militant organization whose goal is the establishment and expansion of a caliphate. Facing backlash from the community and increased security from U.S. and Iraqi forces, the group faced decline until 2011, when it began to grow through its involvement in the Syrian Civil War. In 2013, it changed its name to the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS). Over the course of 2013 and 2014, it quickly took over territory in Syria and Iraq. old_description: The Southern Front was established on February 13, 2014 to consolidate the command structure and military operations of 49 southern opposition brigades attempting to overthrow the Assad Regime. The Southern Front is a self-described moderate opposition group, and is active in the Quneitra, Daraa, Sweida, and Damascus governorates where it often uses guerilla tactics to combat the Syrian army. Throughout 2014, the Southern Front cooperated with former Al Qaeda affiliate Jabhat Fatah al-Sham, formerly known as Jabhat al-Nusra (Al-Nusra), despite tense relations between the two groups. However, the group officially severed ties with Al-Nusra on April 14, 2015 in a statement criticizing Al-Nusra¬ís ideology. In December 2015, the Southern Front attended a conference in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia where opposition groups agreed to negotiate with Assad. However violence in Syria quickly escalated as the Assad Regime and its allies increased their bombing campaign and as the Southern Front pursued its March 2016 campaign against the Islamic State in Daraa. In April 2016, the High Negotiations Committee for the Syrian Revolution and Opposition Forces, a group tasked with nominating representatives to negotiate with Assad after the Riyadh conference, suspended peace talks with the Assad over worsening conditions on the ground in Syria.

old_description: The Taliban (not to be confused with the Tehreek-e-Taliban in Pakistan (TTP)) is a far right Islamist militant organization created in 1994 seeking to establish a strictly Shariah-governed Afghan state. The Taliban achieved this goal in 1996 and ruled Afghanistan through 2001. Since 2001, the Taliban has actively fought to push U.S. and NATO military forces out of Afghanistan and delegitimize the current government of Afghanistan. The Taliban utilizes IEDs, rocket attacks, conventional warfare, unconventional warfare, suicide bombers, mortar strikes, small arms fire, kidnappings, and assassinations to pursue its goals.
description: The Afghan Taliban is an Islamist militant organization established in 1994 during the civil war that followed the Soviet Union’s withdrawal from Afghanistan. It was defeated militarily after it sheltered Al Qa’ida in 2001, but it remains a major challenge for the Afghan government.

old_description: The Three Percenters (III%ers) is a far-right militant organization founded in 2008 following the election of President Barack Obama. Considered to be one of the largest umbrella groups in the antigovernment movement, also known as the patriot/militia movement, III%ers coalesces around the incorrect notion that only 3% of the population fought against the British in the American Revolution. The group is highly decentralized; some chapters are organized as militias, while others are non-paramilitary in nature or only maintain an online presence. Prominent subgroups affiliated with the III%er brand include the III% Security Force, the III% United Patriots, the American Patriots III%, the III% Originals, and more. On January 6, 2021, the group played an active role in storming the U.S. Capitol to disrupt the formalization of Joe Biden¬ís victory in the 2020 presidential election.
